bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Thomas Evans, June 2, 1721

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant Thomas Evans, June 2, 1721, that all the London ships in the colony have lowered their freight rates to £8 but one whom Carter does not believe will find a cargo. He notes the poor crop due to the worms that are wiping out their young tobacco plants.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Thomas Evans, June 2, 1721

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
June 2d. 1721
Mr. Thos. Evans

div1.p:
I gave you the trouble of some Lines a few days agon.
This only Intended as a Short hint to advise that our London Ships
have all Sunk their freight to £8 Except one, and he may lye till
he's blind I believe before he getts full. The General Cry at this
Day is few or none of the Ships will gett Loaded, we have as
Yett a very poor Appearance of making a Crop this Year, The Ground
worme pays our plants off in our beds and all that we plant
Cutts off in a Day or two, this is the General cry report as farr as my
Intelligence reaches, a month or Six weekes hence will Inform
us better how we are like to Succeed but I Shall not add further
at this time but am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . p. 101.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and state have been added for clarity.
